title: Over-Sea; or, England, France and Scotland as seen by a live American ... With numerous illustrations, etc
author: Morford, Henry.
snippet: city-ward, a cruciform Grecian building devoted to ihe pur- poses of the Royal Observatory ; and a little below a hand- some little Ionic temple to the memory of Professor Dugald Stewart; while two or three mounted cannon, taken from the Russians at Sebastopol, overawed the city from the stone wall forming the hill's s uthern boundary. So much for the Calton Hill itself; but the view from it was quite another affair ! Southward and eastward the city, with the view down the whole length of Prince's Street (the Broadway and Fifth Avenue of Edinboro' in one) only broken by the grace- ful Gothic tracery of the Scott Monument. South-westward, Arthur's Seat, its dark brow touched with sunlight through the mist; Salisbury Crags nestling sullenly below; and in the valley at the feet of both, the low, irregular pointed- towered Holyrood House—ehief goal, after all, of most of the pilgrimages paid to the whilouie capital of the Stuarts.

title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: This monument is 350 feet above the level of the sea, and embraces an extensive view of the city and surrounding country, such indeed as is rarely to be obtained in a large city. Looking from the monument westwards, Prince's Street in all its beauty is seen, and thence along to the Corstorphine hills. On the south are the crowded and dingy buildings of the Old Town, covering the ridges that slope from the Castle to Holyrood.

title: The recreations of Christopher North
author: Wilson, John
snippet: It was followed by a plain, sensible, honest, unpretending, common-place, every day sort of a coat — and not, perhaps, of the very best merino. Over it was drawn, with some little difficulty, what had, in its prime of life, attracted universal admiration in Prince's Street, as a blue suriout. Then came your regular olive- coloured great-coal — not braided and embroidered a lit imlihiire — for we scorned to sham travelling-captain — but simphx munditiis, plain in its neatness; not wanting then was your shag-hued wraprascal, betokening that its wearer was up to snafl" — and to close this strange eventful histoiy, the seven-caped Dread-nought, that loved to dally with the sleets and snows — held in calm contempt Boreas, Notus, Auster, Eurus, and "the rest" — and drove bafllcd Winter howling behind the Pole.

title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: Besides its natural beauties, many of the localities, both within and around the city, are remarkable for their historical associations. The places of interest which a visitor should not fail to see are— Prince's Street, the Royal Institution and National Gallery, the Antiquarian Museum, the National Gallery of Paintings, St. Mary's Cathedral, the Register Office and Post Office, the Waverley Station, Theatre Royal, Calton Hill, St. Andrew's Square, and George Street, all in the new part. In the old part—the Assembly Hall, St. Giles's Cathedral, the Parliament House, the Advocates' Library, John Knox's House, Holyrood Palace, the Abbey of Holyrood House, Arthur's Seat, the University, the New Infirmary, Heriot's Hospital, and various places of interest in the new suburbs.

title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: In the old part—the Assembly Hall, St. Giles's Cathedral, the Parliament House, the Advocates' Library, John Knox's House, Holyrood Palace, the Abbey of Holyrood House, Arthur's Seat, the University, the New Infirmary, Heriot's Hospital, and various places of interest in the new suburbs. Prince's Street is the principal street in Edinburgh, and the one in which most of the best hotels are situated. It extends for quite a mile in a straight line from east to west, and, being built upon only one side, has the appearance and character of a terrace—a very striking feature; while in this street is the noble and elegant Gothic spire erected as a monument to the memory of Sir Walter Scott.

title: A Holiday Tour in Europe. Described in a series of letters written for The Public Ledger, etc
author: Cook, Joel.
snippet: The railway, aster running through two tunnels under portions of the city, passes along the bottom of a deep ravine, and sloping up from both sides are gardens surmounted by magnificent buildings, whilst towering above all, on the right-hand side, is Edinburgh Castle. Then emerging from the station, crossing the Waverley Bridge, and going around the magnificent Waverley .Memorial into Prince's Street, the sight, as one passes along in front of the great hotels, is grand indeed. No wonder Dun-Edin and her people are proud.

title: Hanleys; or, Wheels within wheels
author: Caumont, Mary.
snippet: They went together, the brother and sister, right down Prince's Street, looking into the shop-windows, and to Holyrood Palace; and then to John Knox's house; and then to look at the little barn meeting-house, where Joseph had been surprised that night by Uncle Arnold.

title: Wayside notes and fireside thoughts.
author: South, Eudora Lindsay.
snippet: Happy to say, however, this judgment was hasty; we have seen no rain since, and very little smoke. A single glance from our front window up and down Prince's Street revealed the fact that we were in a city of magnificent monuments, handsome modern palaces, and refreshing gardens. Overlooking the city from an elevation to the right appeared old Edinboro

title: Over-Sea; or, England, France and Scotland as seen by a live American ... With numerous illustrations, etc
author: Morford, Henry.
snippet: I was descending the hill, past that spot on the Southern side, between the London Road and Waterloo Place, where the noble pile of the Royal High-School now marks the site once occupied by the Kirk of Fieid (or Church in the Fields) in which Queen Mary's worthless husband, Darnley, was blown up and murdered in February, 1567 ;—past the handsome little Burns Monument, a pillared Grecian temple on base, with winged griffins supporting an hour-glass ;—past the Prison of Edinboro', embattled with more than forty turrets, and notably handsome (to those who only see it from the outside .')—when I saw something fluttering up the flagstaff Jo. the Royal Hotel, down Prince's Street, and recognized, for the first time in weeks, the starry flag which had so lately been raised anew over the last strong-hold of rebellion !

title: The life and correspondence of Andrew Combe ...
author: Combe, George
snippet: I was first disappointed, and then threatened. This, with a considerable feeling of shyness to go to sueh a * grand doetor' as one living in a self-contained house in Prince's Street then seemed in my eyes, was quite enough to rouse my stubbornness. Once committed, I resolved not to yield, and hence the laughable extravaganza which ensued."

title: The Underground City; Or, The Black Indies; (Sometimes Called The Child of the Cavern)
author: Verne, Jules
snippet: There, in this immense natural excavation, Simon Ford built his new cottage, which he would not have exchanged for the finest house in Prince's Street, Edinburgh. This dwelling was situated on the shores of the loch, and its five windows looked out on the dark waters, which extended further than the eye could see.

title: A Holiday Tour in Europe. Described in a series of letters written for The Public Ledger, etc
author: Cook, Joel.
snippet: No wonder Dun-Edin and her people are proud. Even the Champs Elysees, of Paris, cannot compare to the front view from any one of the hotels on Prince's Street across the ravine to the hills beyond, splendid edifices meeting the eye on every side, the Castle on its massive rock in front, with red-coated sentinels guarding the ramparts, the bottom of the ravine a series of lovely gardens, and all made into a landscape in the heart of a great city that I believe is without a rival on either continent. The modern Athens enjoys from nature a position of the highest beauty, which art has adorned in the most thorough manner.

title: In the Western Highlands of Scotland, and holiday notes at Scarborough
author: Cowley, Percy Tunnicliff.
snippet: Edinburgh, as well as the statue, was certainly very grey, and there was scarcely a soul to be seen as the cab drew up with me and my portmanteau at the door of Macgregor's Royal Hotel, Prince's Street. A particularly canny Scot drove me from the Waverley! I found I had no smaller piece of money than half-a-crown, and giving it to him asked him for a shilling change.

title: In the Western Highlands of Scotland, and holiday notes at Scarborough
author: Cowley, Percy Tunnicliff.
snippet: Black says that " In the time of James I, the architecture of the town seems to have been of a very simple description, the houses in general being covered with thatch, and not above twenty feet high." But when I walked down Prince's Street, and looked on the splendid Public Buildings, the Scott Monument, the Old Castle, and the National Gallery, not forgetting the Royal Institution, and the Bank of Scotland, it was somewhat hard to believe that Mr. Black was telling the truth. Truly, Edinburgh is an interesting city.

title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: Sir Walter Scott was born in Edinburgh in August 1771, and died at Abbotsford, September 21, 1S32. In the gardens on the south side of Prince's Street are statues of Livingstone, Adam Black, Professor Wilson, Allan Ramsay, Sir James Simpson, and the late Dean Ramsay.

title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: In one room, devoted to modern pictures, are some fine paintings by Sir Noel Paton, Faed, Erskine, Nicol, Herdman, &c. In a small room on the south side are some beautiful water-colours by Girten, Cox, Cattermole, Nash, Prout, Lewis, &c. Turning to the north, at the west end of Prince's Street is Charlotte Square, in which is the Scottish memorial to the late Prince Consort, an equestrian statue with bas-reliefs on the pedestal. Sir John Steell was the architect.

title: The house with the green shutters,
author: Brown, George Douglas
snippet: " Dear mother/' said the wee sma' Scoatchman — so the hearty Allan dubbed him — " Dear mother, I just write to inform you that I've been out to a grand dinner at Jock Allan's. He met me on Prince's Street, and made a great how-d'ye-do. ' Come out on Thursday night, and dine with me/ says he, in his big way.

title: Our coaching trip,
author: Carnegie, Andrew
snippet: Miss Roxburgh was here called to the front, alongside of Perry, to act as guide into and through the city to our hotel in Prince's Street. The enthusiasm s^rew more and more intense as we came nearer and fresh views were obtained.

title: The life and correspondence of Andrew Combe ...
author: Combe, George
snippet: him return the answer, " I'll no be naething."' His father, never doubting that under this humour of expression there was a tacit approval of his selection of medicine, proceeded to inquire after a suitable person who should take him as an apprentice (an apprenticeship being an indispensable condition of becoming a member of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh) ; and soon arranged with Mr Henry Johnston, who had risen into repute as a general medical practitioner in Edinburgh, that he should receive Andrew under an indenture for the usual term of years. At that time Mr Johnston resided in Prince's Street. He did not sell medicines to the public, but, following the then general custom in Edinburgh (which still prevails in England), he kept in his house a store of them, which he dispensed to his own patients.

title: Peter's letters to his kinsfolk.
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: The prejudice in favour of sticking by the Old Town was so strong among the gentlemen of the trade, that when this bookseller intimated a few years ago his purpose of removing to the New, his ruin was immediately prophesied by not a few of his sagacious brethren. He persisted, however, in his intentions, and speedily took possession of a large and airy suite of rooms in Prince's Street, which had formerly been occupied by a notable confectioner, and whose thresh- hold was therefore familiar enough to all the frequenters of that superb promenade. There it was that this enterprizing bibliopole hoisted his standard, and prepared at once for action.

title: Peter's letters to his kinsfolk.
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: There it was that this enterprizing bibliopole hoisted his standard, and prepared at once for action. Stimulated, I suppose, by the example and success of John Murray, whose agent he is, he determined to make, if possible, Prince's Street to the High-Street, what the other has made Albemarle Street to the Row.

title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: The Register Office and Post Office are at the eastern end of Prince's Street. The Register Office contains all the public registers and records of Scotland.

title: Wayfaring men;
author: Lyall, Edna
snippet: The child greeted him with delight and eagerly showed him a Kodak which Christine had just given him, and with which he was longing to take snap-shots at the people in Prince's Street. " But I mustn't do it.

title: Ruth Farmer. A story
author: Marchbank, Agnes.
snippet: You do not know the misery that underlies the splendour of our great cities. Sometimes when I walk along Prince's Street and see the display of wealth there is all around me, it seems to me as if the words of the Master, ' Sell that thou hast and give to the poor,' had been scornfully, not even 'sorrowfully,' rejected by the world."

title: Zigzag Journeys in Europe: Vacation Rambles in Historic Lands
author: Butterworth, Hezekiah
snippet: The party took rooms on Prince's Street, a thoroughfare one hundred feet wide and a mile in length, graced with noble monuments of art and bowery pleasure-grounds. It is considered one of the most picturesque streets in the world.

title: Self-Raised; Or, From the Depths
author: Southworth, Emma Dorothy Eliza Nevitte
snippet: I will tell you just how it was, as it came to my knowledge. My town house fronted immediately on Prince's Street. You know what a thoroughfare that is?

title: The Edinburgh tales.
author: Johnstone, C. I.
snippet: Printed by WILLIAM TAIT, 107, Prince's Street.
